bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Ralph N. Cresne, January 23, 1920

div1.p: Carter discusses the control of mosquitoes in southern U.S. ports.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Ralph N. Cresne, January 23, 1920
div1.opener:
Memorandum on the control of Yellow-Fever-Conveying Mosquitos
in Florida Ports.
Copy sent liut
January 2123, 1920.
File miss
Y. F. Files
Dr. Ralph N. Cresne,
State Health Officer,
State Board of Health,
Jacksonville, Fla.
Dear Doctor:
div1.p:
I examined at Tampa, Florida, during the past three days
the records of the entries of all the ports of Florida for the calendar
year of 1919. Except for Tampa, Miami, and Key West, no records were
available prior to June 1st. I think, however, that this makes little
difference as entries in January and February (and in Pensacola in
March) are of no importance from a yellow fever standpoint, being
outside the Quarantine seasonal limits.

No vessels from any ports infected or suspected of infection
from Yellow Fever enter at any of the following ports: Fernandina,
Jacksonville, Miami, Boca Grande, St. Andrews or Apalachicola. Vessels
from the last two cleared for ports in Mexico, but none entered direct
from such ports.

For Pensacola, Tampa, and Key West, the case is different.
The only places on the Gulf; Atlantic or Caribbean Seaports at which
yellow fever is believed to exist at present is in Yucatan and Campeche.
There is a permanent focus in Yucatan of which Merida is the probable
center and of which Progresso is the preferable port of exit. The
portion of Mexico soutwest of Yucatan on the Isthmus of Tehuantepec is,
I believe, not above suspicion, yet I do not know that it is infected.
-2-
Of the ports in this section, Progresso is easily the most dangerous
having direct communication with Merida and being the port of exit
for Merida passengers.

The Laguna de Carmen in Campeche and Frontera should be
counted as suspicious. There was a regular line from Pensacola, the
Stesmare Hornot and Oregon, to these ports and to Bluefields and Cape
Gracias (Nicaragua) in logs--mahogany, cedar, etc. Farther south
are the Bay Islands opposite the Mosquito Coast and Belize. They are Honduran territory I think. Both
these islands and the coast mentioned are believed to be free from
fever and have been so for a long time. We are able to have quite
a close supervision of the Honduran Coast near to these Islands through
the United Fruit Company's stations at Tela and Ceiba. Further east
still is Cape Gracias A Dios, another log port; as is Bluefields
south of it in Nicaragua. Both have long been very healthful ports
and I believe are so still.

In the summer of 1918 and last spring and early sooner
there was yellow fever in Guatemala and Salvador on the Pacific
coast. This was taken in charge by the Health Authorities, the In-
ternational Health Board furnishing most of the funds and the work
being first under the supervision of Senior Surgeon White of this
Service and afterwards of General Gorgas. This work is reported as
having been completely successful. At any rate there is extremely
little direct passenger travel across the mountain from the Pacific
to the Caribbean Coast and we have heard of no infection on the
Caribbean coast of Central America, nor do I believe that there is
-3-
any. Even if there were, it would be little apt to show up at any of
the ports I have mentioned in Central America, Bluefields, Cape
Gracias, the Bay Islands, Belize or the Mosquito coast.

The largest Mexican trade to the Florida ports is from the
oil fields of Tampico, Tuxpam, etc. These ports are certainly free
from Yellow Fever, and if they become infected we ought, and I believe
would, know it at once because they have a large number of people
susceptible to yellow fever; Americans, English, Scotch and Germans
living there. It is not at all probable then that they would become
infected without our knowing it almost immediately.

Pensacola from June to December, inclusive, had one schooner
(July), light, from Program: four steamers, in cargo (logs), from
Frontera. Two of these, however, were not during quarantine season
(in November and December). She has, however, a regular line of two
small steamers bringing logs from Frontera, Bluefields and Cape
Gracias; two trips are recorded from Cape Gracias and three from
Bluefields. The Frontera and Progreso trade is not free from risk
of infection. Progresso is the outlet for Merida and Yucatan pass-
engers, and that country is infected in the Yellow Fever (Merida and
some other parts of Yucatan).

Tampa had twenty-three steamers from the oil fields: Fif-
teen during the quarantine season (March to November, inclusive).
This trade is at present safe. A large trade, forty-seven schooners,
-4-
from the Bay Islands (Rnatan and Benacca) and Belize bring cocoanuts.
This trade is also, I think, at present safe. If, however, yellow
fever developed on the Caribbean coast of Guatemala, or Honduras
(Port Barrios, Livingston or Tela) this safety might not continue.
Of suspicious trade it had four schooners bringing logs from the
Laguna. I will add that the Bay Islands and Belize are probably the
safest ports in the Central American litoral. Cape Gracias is also
a very safe port. Progresso, Laguna and Frontera should count, the
first as infected, the other two as suspicious.

Key West shows twenty vessels from the oil ports, seventeen
in quarantine season (March to November, inclusive), seventeen schooners
from the Bay Islands, Belize and Bluefields, fourteen of which were
in quarantine season and seven from Cape Gracias. All of the above
count as safe enough traders. The only entries from infected or
suspected ports are two steamers from Progresso and one from Front-
era; the first two called for supplies.

It is fair to say then that the trade from ports infected
with or suspected of yellow fever of last year was small in amount
to any Florida port, , and that to most Florida ports there was
none. The statistician at Tampa is quite positive that there will
be a considerable increase in cocoanut imports into Tampa, which
are large already, and although less positive of the log trade from
Frontera and Laguna to Pensacola and Tampa, he looks for a consid-
erable increase of this also. He does not think there will be any
increase in trade to Key West from suspicious ports.

It would seem than that the only ports by which the intro-
duction of yellow fever into Florida was at all threatened last
year were Pensacola, Tampa and Key West, and in this order. If the
opinion of Mr. Skinnerron, above quoted, be correct, the difference
in proportionate risk by the above three ports will be increased
in 1920 and in the same order.

From some knowledge of the local conditions at the three
ports mentioned, I believe measures to control the Aedes Calopus
Mosquito (Yellow Fever Mosquito) would be very much more difficult
and expensive in Key West than in either of the other places--it
not, I think, having a piped water supply--and taking this into
consideration together with the lessened risk at this place, I
would recommend that in this work preference be given first to
Pensacola and second to Tampa and Key West only in third place.
This is for the purpose of getting a maximum amount of sanitary
benefit per unit of expenditure. I would like to add that the con-
trol of this mosquito, involving as it does the control of the
other domestic species (Culex fatigans), in addition to the pro-
tection given against yellow fever and dengue, will in any town
with a piped water supply, pay in addition well over a hundred per-
cent of the expenditure in increased comfort.
div1.closer:
Yours respectfully, H. R. Carter, M.D.
United States Public Health Service. HRC/B
